column1: Before 1 January 2023, will Amazon announce that it will spin off Amazon Web Services (AWS)?
column6: ['Business', 'Technology', 'US Politics', 'US Policy']
Passage of time
All in.
dodge city made a strategic call because they have no choice secondary to the evolution of technology
only if @dowser allows it
the FBI has no choice but to participate
You would hear rumors

CIA won’t allow a spin-off but the big secret is an Amazon crypto currency much like points you earn from using a credit card transferable to your back account much like eBay and PayPal but crypto Amazon already has a platform for crypto currency trading the purpose is to stimulate velocity of money that’s the real reason the Fed stopped reporting mzm anyway more information and someone going to have to pay me to stop forecasting
Reduction with the passing of time. But also, in the latest earnings report AWS was the crown jewel of Amazon's business. It would hardly be rational to spin it off at this point.
Likely to occur in a bull market, not a bear market
Not happening
AWS is a major diversification in Amazon's income. It would be hugely detrimental to the company to spin it off.
Seems unlikely, there are no noises it's on the cards.

Amazon has shown no desire to spin-off businesses in past, so a spin-off of this size seems even less palatable. AWS uses the retail side as way to test products before launch, and solicit features to build. Retail gets discounted services, and a large org that will make tools for them. It is a very symbiotic relationship. There is no "harm" to them staying together, except the political risk - which is small since its a fringe discussion from a political party that is likely losing influence across 2022. Based on this, Amazon has no strong urgency to consider this path in the near future. There is no rumors or claims from amazon about a spin-off being seriously considered, and that is a major task for a company that size, so Iis unlikely that any formal announcement is near (even if it does occur one day due to changing politics).
Now it has more probability that they will split the stock before they do a float.
Very unlikely
Hard to predict what new CEO will do. AWS is his baby though so he understands intrinsic value of it more than anyone.
They won't voluntarily disgorge their revenue "rising star". i have trouble believing the fed will move fast enough to force such an event by Dec 31
Spinning of AWS will not make Amazon - The Everything Store - any less of a predator monopolist.
updating -1

Benefits: - Seemingly no direct benefits from spinning off AWS. AWS is currently makes up the largest proportion of profit and profit growth for Amazon. This profit is used to enable aggressive discounting in e-commerce (Amazon's products on amazon.com) and brick and mortar stores (WholeFoods), driving revenue growth in these areas. - If we measure public perception of Amazon via its stock price, this has been at an all-time high since August 2020. Splitting off AWS would severely harm this, as Amazon has not yet shown profits (or even an intention to make a profit) in other business areas.
All of Amazon's profits appear to be coming from AWS. Not likely they would spin it off with Amazon's retail business unprofitable.

I had missed the fact that Amazon is now breaking out AWS in its filings: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1018724/000101872421000028/amzn-20210930.htm#i938dbbcfcf0645268507d22b13fb8f8e_76 (Please see page 23.).

AWS represents around 50% of Amazon's net earnings [1], so we are talking about basically splitting Amazon into two, i.e. not a minor divestment. Examples of similar break ups of top 5 market cap companies = AT&T, Standard Oil, American Tobacco i.e. 3 in 100 years. Any others?
I am not sure there is any interest in Amazon to do this. AWS is very profitable. Historically I don’t recall them doing many spin-offs.

The recent breakup of three major conglomerates indicates that the market is valuing more focused businesses higher than businesses that try to do too many things. I believe AWS is more valuable as a standalone company than as a subsidiary of Amazon.
Adjusting for passage of time. No indications, though I think indications aren’t all that likely much in advance if an announcement.
holding
holding
Lowering for passage of time.

Two reasons to spin off a major part of your company: to create value for shareholders or because your forced into it by regulators (or you think regulators are going to force you into it so you get it over and done with). It is doubtful that such a move could create value for shareholders as Amazon.com runs on AWS and it is clear from the history of the company that AWS is tightly integrated with the rest of the company. Since AWS constitutes much of the underlying infrastructure of the rest of the company it makes no sense to split it off. Amazon uses funds from AWS to research and enter new industries and it has an excellent record of innovative success. Spinning off AWS would significantly disrupt this model of growth. Not sure how regulators could make a case that Amazon with AWS is a monopoly and spinning it off would fix it.
Adoption of crypto-cloud-storage (esp. Holo) will not have proceeded so far as to force a move by amazon concerning AWS by end of 2022. Getting rid of their cash-cow seems like a bad strategic move.
Adjusting for passage of time. This still makes sense, even if they aren’t talking about it.
Affirming prior opinion.
Why? Would crush multiple on remainco
Only way this would happen is if congress mandated such
High growth, high profit business that will do well as a separate entity in stock markets. Also, a separate business that has no synergy with retail business.

Yes, if they are planning to accept crypto currency as a payment method, it would mean that they are almost ready to spin off the company. They already implemented step one, by changing the CEO, this will be step two and three. The fourth step will be the announcement. I think if they announce it in the fourth quarter next year. They had a long time to plan this, since 2013, when the German antitrust started investigations into the company and also currently with the ongoing American antitrust investigations.

The company has already started with there preparations for the spin off, they are following the 6 steps for a successful spinoff, there was a article in CFO in 2018 by Tze-Liang Chaim and Lasida Klinsukond that explained the most effective way to do a spin off. Amazon have already implemented the first step by appointing a new CEO. The next step will be getting the operating model right, and I think that is what the company is currently doing now. The next step will be devising a short and long term tax strategy and then the fourth stage is preparing the people for the change, that is when the announcement will come into play. I will not include the rest of the steps, because they are not relavent to the question. So depending on how quick they can get trough the planning stages, I do think that there is a very high probability of the announcement to happen before 2023. But there are manu unseen variables and factors to take into account.
For: regulatory pressure Against: not in AMZN interest, 2023 is soon
government interference will force it
Given how much important this segment of their business is to Amazon and the current CEO is from AWS.
Unlikely anti-trust arguments would be successful, especially as economies of scale benefit the businesses, and in turn, the end users.

I think it is unlikely in this short of a time frame, as the split would have a serious effect upon Amazon stock price. Right now, AWS subsidizes many of the other operations. I think the risk of antitrust rulings needs to be higher/more eminent for a spin off to crystallize. It could happen as part of a negotiation before heavy regulation perhaps, but I think it would be on a longer timeline.

AWS is responsible for 12% of Amazon revenue but 59% of its profit (1). Its the main driver behind Amazon's market value. The retail business is (and probably always will be) a high volume - low margin business that on its own should have a value closer to Walmart than to Apple. There is zero incentive from Amazon's stand to break up. Not only does AWS subsidize the retail business, it also provides it with reams of data and the expertise to use it. Besides Amazon there are 3 more groups to consider: - Antitrust (government) - Customers - Shareholders
Amazon will never spinoff their cloud computing business.

Jassy has often been asked if Amazon could be planning to separate AWS and turn it into its own business. Historically, Jassy has said no. https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/11/aws-ceo-we-would-follow-the-law-if-regulators-demand-amazon-spin-out.html
No as AWS helps to pay for Virgin Galactica Blue Horizon…(inside joke) … space- craft for commercial space flight

This makes sense for a variety of reasons, mostly regulatory. AWS is in a different business, and it makes sense for it to stand alone. Shareholders would receive shares of both companies, and most likely would approve of the deal. I’d give it a higher percentage if top management weren’t so adamant they won’t do this. But they may well change their minds.

I agree with most forecasters that it is currently unlikely that Amazon spins off its most profitable division. Howerver, as the due date of the question is still one and a half years ahead, I think that a likeliness of 2% or lower is too low given the time horizon. However, I do not know any reasonable way to calculate a probability. Therefore, I settle for 6% and will reduce the probability over time.
Extremely low chance that Amazon spins off its most profitable part.

New CEO Andy Jassy comes from AWS, which should signal strongly where now-Chairmen Bezos thinks the engine of the company lies. AWS contributes just 12% of Amazon's revenue but 47% of their operating income.[1] As such it is the profit engine that drives growth across the business.

Most of Amazon's profit comes from AWS. Spinning off will significantly and negatively impact the stock price. Amazon will delay it / fight it, I'm assuming that they won't do it unless forced. Congress is looking at some anti-trust laws (such as the Ending Platform Monopolies Act), but it's unclear if and when they will pass, and even then it will take longer for any significant action to force this spin-off.

I'm just getting started on this. There's a lot of political pressure that could be mustered here. Yet it's unclear how much energy Congress or the Biden regulatory team will be able to generate at this point. It's been a long time since regulators in the US have been activists, and longer still since people have wanted them to be. I see potential, but I'm not sure how much of that can be realized before the end of 2022 or whether it's enough to force Amazon's hand. .
Anti-big tech sentiment is just about the only thing Democrats and Republicans agree on. There will be a lot of pressure on Amazon to do something, this would probably reward shareholders well.

AWS is what allows them to subsidize their costs as a grocery store, logistics company, and overall retail juggernaut. Without AWS, Amazon runs into some serious structural issues surrounding Prime and data collection/storage. Amazon would likely not spin off AWS on their own unless it was the easy way to remove a government oversight issue as Anti-trust isn't likely to effect the company in the near future.

This was my position from November 2020 in the sister question, as there's a little more stability in the world (IMO), the 2% comment is no longer valid, despite this question having a longer open period.

If the CIA et al. choose to stay with AWS' services, I think they would fear attracting attention during a spin-off. I therefore expect antitrust scrutiny to be kept to symbolic words, so as to not force a spin-off.

I think that Amazon will hold onto AWS for as long as possible, since it provides such a significant portion of their revenue - along with the possibility of using stored data for developing better business strategies. However, if antitrust cases move past Google and Facebook advertising and Amazons marketplace stuff in the coming years, I think Amazon/AWS could be a likely next target. In that case, Amazon would definitely get ahead of the curve and create a spinoff, but certainly not before that point.

I'm still a bit unclear how much of a role Jeff Bezos has in these high-level decisions as Executive Chairman, but if he has veto power it seems to me to be highly unlikely this will happen during his tenure, since Amazon has never spun out a business. The case for spinning off AWS is a good one from both the perspective of being a bargaining chip to keep antitrust regulators away and from a business standpoint (since some customers are avoiding AWS because they compete with Amazon's retail side). See for example: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/24/former-amazon-senior-engineer-calls-for-aws-spinoff.html
